title: A Decision Support System for Self-management of Low Back Pain - a Randomized Controlled Trial for the selfBACK Project
description_brief: The intervention consists of a digital decision support system delivering a weekly plan of suggested activities that the participant can use to self-manage their low back pain (LBP) via an smartphone app.
description_detailed:
The selfBACK intervention consists of the selfBACK system, that provides the participants with an individually tailored weekly plan of suggested activities to use in their self-management of low back pain.

The selfBACK system constitutes a data-driven decision support system that uses case-based reasoning to capture and reuse participant cases to suggest the most suitable self-management plan for participants. The system is an intelligent system delivering self-management plans tailored to individual participant characteristics. Information about participant characteristics is collected via a (baseline) questionnaire, weekly self-reports via the app on symptom progression etc., and a wristband that detect daily number of steps. The weekly plans are presented in an app to participants.

The weekly plan includes three categories of content;

1. information/education
2. recommended daily number of steps
3. recommended strength and flexibility exercises

Outcomes are collected as baseline, 6 weeks, 3, 6, 9 months.
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is a digital decision support system (the selfBACK app) that delivers weekly, tailored self-management plans (physical activity/step goals, strength and flexibility exercises, and education) for people with nonspecific low back pain — i.e., a non-pharmacologic, app-based behavioral/self-management intervention rather than a drug or biologic. citeturn0search1turn0search7

Act: Key extracted details — name: selfBACK; format: smartphone app delivering weekly tailored self-management plans; tailoring method: case-based reasoning using baseline questionnaires, weekly self-reports, and step-count wristband data; trial design: multinational RCT comparing selfBACK + usual care versus usual care alone (primary outcome pain-related disability). No drug or biologic is involved in the intervention. Sources: protocol paper, pilot study, project reports and trial listings. citeturn0search1turn0search7turn0search3turn0search4

Reflect: Classification check — does not match any Alzheimer’s categories (disease-targeted biologic or small molecule), nor is it a cognitive enhancer or a neuropsychiatric-symptom treatment. It is a digital self-management intervention for low back pain, so the correct category for the Alzheimer’s-targeted taxonomy is 'N/A'. Web searches confirmed no drug/biologic is associated with this trial (it is the selfBACK app). citeturn0search1turn0search2
